cons: A feeling that the boat has been sinking for many years. The lack of major good news. The constant uncertainty about the future, which negatively impacts the employee morale. They recently majored the number of hours you must work in a week for the same pay (normal week went from 35hrs/w to 37.5hrs/w.) Communication is a bit lacking. You need to go on the intranet (which isn't super easy to navigate through) to find out about nominations and even job postings. When people leave no memo is sent. Senior leadership changes so much and so often, it's hard to keep track and evaluate.

pros: Great experience and education on selling.  I had great sales training, and many great colleagues.  Most of the managers were very pleasant to work with. The salary and benefits were very generous.  I was able to manage my own time as long as I met my numbers.  My manager worked with me about once per month, and was a great coach.
cons: The company does not have a culture which embraces hiring reps from within the company who are good reps in good standing.  Once you come in as a territory business manager, there you will stay unless you are willing to go back to the home office.  Territory changes every year, bonus plan changed every year, with senior management making it very difficult for good reps in geographies or states where there were a number of managed care restrictions to earn much or compete well.

review_title: Not a results oriented company and does not value its people
pros: Compensation, clean biopharma industry.  An opportunity to gain good experience
cons: Shrinking in size.  Does not follow a consistent strategy,   Regularly  implementing reorganizations that seem to be more based on an executive's attempt to justify how they are improving the company rather than a sound and consistent business strategy.  Management seems to think the solution is a revolving door of new people rather than building upon its people's expertise, accumulated knowledge and drive to help the company perform and evolve.  Many many cases of the companies senior management acting unethically.  Some of these cases have resulted in the settlement of large law suites.  Individuals at all levels within the company go from being stars to being let go in an instant because someone decides talking poorly about  another group or individual will help them get ahead.    This approach destroys morale and working together as a team to deliver results.  Evaluates people on whose in favor rather than on a performance basis.  Goal setting for most individuals is short term rather than long term.  This is a lost company that is a shell of its former greatness.

review_title: You need to weigh the pros and cons.
job_title: Technical Specialist in East Syracuse, NY
pros: Noble mission; decent benefits; interesting industry; multiple locations options.  Some very flexible working options, depending on who you are.  Pay is good comparatively (especially for Syracuse, NY); Prestigious resume builder. Some folks who are from the old days are valuable, intelligent and provide great training to "newbies" out of college and those looking to get into more corporate level environments, but unfortunately, they are a dying breed.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic; management heavy (many layers); very conservative in various segments of work; extremely political; "good old boys club" to the max, relatively diversified workforce racially, but women and those with ethnic backgrounds are not usually in management positions.  VERY limited growth potential (I was actually told in my interview by HR director that all director level jobs were sourced outside the company.)  Very very dependent on high levels of education in roles that might not require it; outsourcing people who have run the plant successfully to save money; lack of transparency with public; consistent fear of negative publicity leads management to make poor choices.  I could go on and on.  Working here literally made me sick to my stomach.

pros: Complex, global challenges present good opportunities for professional growth.  Company has good reputation.  Overall good co-workers.
cons: Recent staffing cuts have been too deep in some areas, others appear to be unaffected.  Work life balance can be difficult to achieve in some departments, burn-out is a real risk.  Salaries are a bit below competitors for everyone but the senior management (whose salaries are above market-level).  Departments are still a bit insulated and act in the department self interest, rather than an enterprise-wide view.  Some of the restructuring seems to have been poorly thought out.  The company is flush with cash, but some of the facilities are in a severe state of disrepair.  Company benefits have suffered (such as the quality of the cafeteria).

pros:
BMS Redwood City is focused on biologics development, from target discovery, protein design and production, to translational research. People have the opportunity to personally impact projects, with the goal of developing efficacious therapeutics. Engagement across groups is encouraged and rewarded.

There have been restructurings over the last few years of various groups, the overall effect has been increased throughput of protein production and lead discovery, leading to faster development of biologics. Projects have been pared to focus on fewer, but higher priority targets.

Within the last year, benefits have been improved for all employees. Working hours are relatively flexible as people live and commute from around the bay area. The Redwood City site has been continually invested in and improved.
cons:
Many of the mid-level managers are relatively new to their roles, which can be positive or negative depending on where you are in your career.

Some people may be disproportionately affected by changes to organization and project prioritization.

Three separate R&D sites across US make cross-site collaboration difficult.

review_title: What an amazing company to work for!!!
pros:
Strong collaboration between groups (I noticed at a training seminar how rare this is at other companies, but seems commonplace at BMS)
Boston grade pay but cheaper cost of living in Devens without the horrible daily commute into Boston
Bonus payout was great last year
Phenomenal pipeline in many diseases and leader in immuno-oncology
Management and senior management that seems to truly care about the individual
Daily reminders on who we really work for...the patient!
Great co-workers
Work/life balance
I love working here...there is a true sense of pride every morning I drive by that BMS sign.
Was really impressed during my first couple of months here when we were short on hands and our Director came and helped out in the lab for a couple hours.  Love that when our VP visits, he not only inspects the lab, but goes into drawers and asks questions about what people are working on (I appreciate they get involved).
cons:
They could open up something in the Southeast so I can get away from these winters  :)
Always busy (this isn't a true negative, but it does make focusing time on novel projects or new technologies a lesson in time management)

review_title: Good company to get comfortable at
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in Redwood City, CA
pros: Excellent work-life balance (most of the time, there is no expectation of more than 40 hours a week), flexibility in scheduling (people routinely come between 6 and 9am and leave 2 to 7pm), Friday afternoons off in summer, Xmas week off, generous maternity leave policy, above-average salary and benefits (bonuses, commuter benefits). Very family-friendly and there are many employees with babies and small children.  Employees as a whole are very personable and friendly. Pros certainly outweigh cons.
cons: Very hierarchical and set in traditions. The difference between PhDs and non-PhDs is strongly felt, likewise, chemistry vs. biology, immunology vs. cancer biology. Employees in RWC are intelligent and hard-working, but outside of this location, the company feels like a large, slow-moving, corporation with no sense of urgency (slow software, dead links, non-response to emails, a "not my problem" attitude). Support services (HR, purchasing, benefits...) have been outsourced or relocated to Puerto Rico/India/Phillipines and can be frustrating to deal with.

job_title: MBA Marketing Intern in Princeton, NJ
pros:
- Work experience with a top Pharma company
- Holistic marketing experience with many opportunities for growth
- Several networking opportunities with senior leaders
- Many networking opportunities with other interns
cons:
- Selection criteria for full-time offers was very unclear which left a bad taste in several people's mouth. Several people requested not to be offered full time positions based on how they were treated, manged and office environment.
- Work environment is a bit passive aggressive and political. Low sense of community and shared goals.

review_title: It was a good place to work, needs to reduce bureaucracy.
pros:
Outside vendors take you seriously.
Upper management is taking on the challenges facing Big Pharma instead of burying their heads in the sand like the others.
They have well-run regulatory and research operations groups.
cons:
It's a country club for some, a sweatshop for others.  Your experience at the company will depend greatly on what group you're in.  Also don't get too good at something or else you'll get stuck with it.   If you can call in favors with the BMS bureaucracy to get things done you will succeed.  If you actually expect others to do their jobs you will fail.
Very process-focused, especially in IT groups.  They'll spend 4 hours debating how someone else should do 30 minutes of work.  Decisions are made in an ad-hoc manner making it hard to develop a standard way of doing things.

review_title: The ultimate goal is twice the work with half the people in a quarter of the time without mistakes
job_title: QC Analyst in East Syracuse, NY
pros: Good location, pay and benefits
cons: Rigid adherence to lean six sigma has cultivated a culture where efficiency and the bottom line are the first priority. Employees are expected to take on more and more responsibility without increased compensation. There is an expectation that all task will be performed without mistakes. If a mistake is made, a TrackWise investigation is launched and corrective actions are put in place that add complexity to the task. This increases the chance of additional steps being missed, thus perpetuating additional investigations and corrective actions. There is a lot of pressure to meet unreasonable deadlines set by management that have no clue about the timeframe it takes to complete different aspects of the project. Management is there to further their careers and will say yes to every request in order to make themselves stand out. Employees are expendable. The more you give the more they take without advancement.

pros: As many other reviews say, pipeline is good and most co-workers are great and understanding. Big company, so you can move around to explore different things. Devens is a good site and I approve of the Devens site head.
cons:
I’ve had a very demotivating 2017 at BMS. 
- No upward mobility for associate scientists. We are stuck in the lab forever
- we don’t get to go to conferences and meetings
- exploring other opportunities are looked down upon 
- the entire thing about “collaboration” is a farce. Some managers in my department tell their groups not to share data. 
- no opportunity to present work to senior leadership team.
- lots of talented people leaving
- they care too much about the money but they don’t know where to invest (some departments)
- hostile work environment to women. I’ve been subject to several sexist remarks by male colleagues.
- retaliation against employees who want to move within the company.
- Incompetent HR.
- they treat contractors like dirt.

job_title: Associate Scientist II in Hopkinton, MA
pros: Good stability. Some employees are great. They are willing to relocate people from all over the country. They are also willing to hire entry level employees into higher positions (can be pro or con)
cons: Dysfunctional work environment. Employees asked to take work home on weekends and vacations, also expected to work long hours. Unwilling to devote time or money to keep up with the industry standards (many archaic practices). Culture is very resistant to change, with A LOT of negativity. Some disrespectful employees are not kept in check - allowed to run their mouth and put other colleagues down without consequences. Limited potential for growth, many employees hired into Associate Scientist I level - everything from fresh out of undergrad with no experience to someone with 7 years of experience all hired into this level.

pros:
Interesting work is available if you are willing to go outside of your comfort zone and sway away from the traditional career path. 
The people are great to work with, passionate about making a difference for patients. 
Great pipeline indicating a successful future. 
Great facilities and a social work environment. Environmentally conscious.
Unlike another review I read on here, I have not experienced any form of discrimination and am shocked to hear of it. I find everyone to be friendly, inclusive and respectful: and it has the coolest and most supportive HR team I’ve come across.
cons:
Still on the journey to streamline processes, but getting there. 
Tries to be innovative but still risk averse in some areas of the business.  
Lean organisation so less opportunity to progress upwards without relocating, albeit lateral moves around the business is encouraged.

review_title: Great company, minus the bureaucracy and lack of diversity
pros:
- The people at BMS are passionate about science and patient health
- Leadership appears to be genuinely invested in addressing the challenges that they face as an organization
- Easily some of the sharpest and brightest people (top to bottom) I’ve ever worked with
cons:
- Too much bureaucracy (i.e. it takes a LONG time to get anything done because there are so many people that need to be involved in making the simplest decisions)
- Lack of diversity in most areas (functions and geographies).
- BMS is extremely lean - in its efforts to drive down costs, they’ve cut way too deep in a number of key areas, which places unreasonable expectations on its understaffed teams.

review_title: Ask for it in writing before you say yes
pros: It is a reputable pharmaceutical company among its peers, better pay for same role and higher overall pay range when compared to other pharmaceutical companies, nice people
cons: Bait and switch tactics were used to get you to accept the position, lack of equality from dept to dept - one dept has resources for office supplies while other don't due to "budget constraints", lack of communications among functional groups, BMS cut many perks still held by competitors which no longer makes them competitive among there peers that do offer such things, there is definitely something wrong when your own line manager says she would "understand if you choose to go somewhere else" when your primary reason for choosing that company is now something they cannot fulfill and refuses to give you a time frame of when it might even be reconsidered as something they hold true on

pros:
-Respectful full-time employees to contractors
-A company culture and operating cadence that closely resembles the military
-Motivated and driven coworkers that understand the same values and believe in their work
cons:
-I'm a contract employee so.....Have to figure something out when the contract ends 
-It's a far drive (personal choice of where to live)

pros: BMS seemed like a great company to work with. They have a long history of success. They were eager to talk with me for a leadership position. They brought me onsite for face to face interviews, even arranged phone interviews with this who could not attend in person. All asked many, many behavioral questions and very few technical questions. The common theme was, "What is your passion for this job?".
cons: They never followed up after the interview. I had to send a few emails to HR to understand their decision process.  I finally called the recruiter one day to ask the status of the position and on that very same day, the HR person finally got back to me saying the original HR person no longer supports this position and has passed it along to another HR person. And to top it off, I submitted an expense report they encouraged me to submit. I've not received a reimbursement check or an email stating when I can expect reimbursement.

review_title: Proud of the work I do - Company suffers from Big Pharmaitis
pros: Innovative science, especially interesting immune therapy for hem/onc space - deep pipeline - decent benefits but pretty average.  Enjoys high satisfaction ratings from customers
cons: Compensation not commensurate with competitors - raises low and slow to come.  Too many layers-home office out of touch with changes in marketplace at customer level.  Metrics no longer realistic- business model is broken for today's healthcare environment.  Ask employees to think outside the box but when anyone speaks up it's clear it's not really what they want to hear.  Extremely difficult to advance career without having to relocate to NJ -no upward mobility for field-based positions.  Politics are suffocating.  Too much jockeying for position and promotions not based on merit.

review_title: Has become very politically driven lately-- real work done is down to 1/3 in IT
pros: Room for bringing sensible solutions- but political cloud is too wasteful to maximize investment. Great place to work towards retirement, if you continue to dodge the bullet. People tend to stay longer simply because the environment is risk-averse and it's easy to play the blame-game and shuffle the "dogs" to retain the throne at D8 level and up.
cons: Personal bias overtakes most cost-effective alternatives, and that leads to customer dissatisfaction after several 100ks lost and lost opportunity/time-- sad! Hiring has become a joke lately. Even D5 and D6 require internal push form sr. mgmt for preferred candidates, which keep the most qualified and suited people out-of-luck.

pros: Compensation is fair, retirement benefits with up to 6% company match on 401K. Some remote flexibility, though to be fair, in many departments dependent on how well you are liked by the manager. Vacation time is good with 4 weeks after 8 years, plus 4 personal holidays based on a full year of employment, and not limited on sick days per year.
cons: Constant reorganizations, resulting in major layoffs. Facility shut downs more prominent - three sites over the course of the next two years causing serious angst/rumors among employees who remain loyal to the end. Poor management styles, resulting in disgruntled employees. Always on edge due to constant "restructuring" of company. Poor decision-making in trying to save money, yet when projects fail they cost more to fix, equaling wasted profits. Many employees who give extra effort are not recognized.

review_title: Great company and great place to work!
pros: I've been with BMS for a year and a half and couldn't be happier. The work environment promotes working together and makes it a more relaxed work space. There is always something going on to get involved with the company and the community. I feel that my ideas and voice are heard and that my leadership encourages me.
cons:
The only negative is that some groups treat their contractors differently than the BMS employees. The work at the company, therefore, I treat my contractor pool as if they were a BMS employee. BMS could do a better job with making the contract positions into full-time BMS positions. 

The BMS Help Desk also has a lot to be desired. It is outsourced and the each encounter I have had has taken days to get my issue resolved when the issue could have been resolved within minutes if an actual BMS employee were answering my call that knows the system and has the ability to think outside the box.

pros: Great company - good salaries and bonuses and stock options. Great people. (Only one group which is horrible there)
cons: Just don't work in the Digital Hub group which is full of clicks. And if you don't agree with everything, they black ball you and get rid of you. If you're not in their inner circle or if you didn't come from Pfizer like the initial team that started this group came from, most likely hard to fit in and they will make like miserable for you,

job_title: Process Development Upstream in Syracuse, NY
pros: On a personal level, most people are very smart and nice.  There is a lot of work that needs to get done.  You are allowed to be yourself and speak freely.
cons: Upper management is unapproachable and does not care about what you have to say.  If they are listening and like what they hear, be sure that you WILL NOT get credit for the idea.  They consistently rotate their Jr. workforce of contract workers.  They are trained for two years and then thrown away.  Essentially, they are wasting well trained employees and driving managers crazy by forcing them to constantly train new workers as well as deal with horrible communication issues and pressing research deadlines.   The Jr. staff are the only workers getting their hands dirty and some mid-level staffers are literally only there to kiss ass and spread rumors.  The ones that are actually productive are pushed to their limit with no end in sight.

review_title: "Talk the talk" but unfortunately rarely "walk" it!
pros: Some great products, well established heritage in Pharma & nice offices! Pay and benefits decent in my experience
cons: Mired in outdated & often cumbersome processes adding little value, extremely risk averse in general and rarely innovative in their business approach. Culture of "first make no mistakes / keep your head down" often results in under performance & long mediocre service. Weak & ineffectual middle management appears common - little value added to the business by these people , &  very poor at developing internal talent which inevitably leads to frustration and a lot of good people leaving. Would like to be considered as "Biopharma" in approach & outlook but well adrift of this currently

review_title: The organization is full of politically engaged people, who escape downsizing, and have moved up to cause bigger harm.
pros: Just as others mentioned-- salary and overall comps. are reasonable (not great). Flexible schedule in some groups. Company is perceived as better than average due to recent "String of Pearls" strategy to bring a robust pipeline picture for wall street. Good for investor ROI.
cons: The biggest obstruction is the pockets of senior Mgmt killing innovation, fair competition, and surrounding with yes men/women to shield themselves. Strong resistance to change, and wasteful spending on ill-defined goals have really wasted millions in IT areas. After all, it is neither a good message for a few productive people there, nor for the business who repeatedly get burnt from ill-manged poorly delivered IT stuff. Yet star rewards are used as a cup of starbucks-easy to get, but seriously do they mean anything(?), are they well deserved??

review_title: The NACC in Tampa is an awesome place to work!
pros: BMS offers a chance to help develop and deliver treatments for the most serious diseases.  I appreciate having a direct line of sight between what I do and the patients we serve.  The benefits are good, the people I work with in Tampa are great, and I'm really excited about the future of the company.  The leadership team has come through on their promises and are a joy to work with.
cons: Some of the business processes are rocking state of the art thinking from the 1990's.  It can be difficult to get offsite people to collaborate on making the process better, and there seems to be particular push back on increasing visibility and accountability.

review_title: Bristol Myers Squibb: A good company, but needs to do a better job of identifying and rooting out bad/rouge managers
pros: This company offers a great benefits package and competitive salary.  The company does a good job of communicating all relevant business information to employees and has a culture of openness as far as what is going on with the company and senior management.
cons: Although the company has good policies in place, there is a lack of civility and respect by local (lower level) management toward employees. Cronyism is rampant throughout the regional area.  Although this may not be entirely systematic, the company has failed to get a good grasp on the problem and handle it effectively.  This results in a culture that breeds a hostile work environment within a local region.

pros: Salary and benefits are good and on par with other pharma companies.  Direct management understands the role and value of MSLs and supports development.  There is very open communication with the internal medical team and the field.
cons: Constant change without a clear rationale or focus on external customer.  Management does not address needs of external customers or listen to input on how the company can address the challenges facing our company. The most important customer is upper management and deliverable is a metric.  Layoffs that helped VP make her bonus hurt our team and negatively impacted BMS in both sales and perception of company's commitment.

job_title: Research Associate in Redwood City, CA
pros: Amazing, incredible and welcoming future cafeteria plan for employees which is on display as one enters the lobby.Truly thankful to the Management for the cafeteria plan. Finally after 12+ years I look forward to team building during lunches.Thank you.  The outdoor BBQ stand is one of the greatest management technology innovation that the employees will be able to enjoy at the Redwood City site. Pat on the back. Lovely and exotic plants and trees have been planted in the newly paved parking lot. Very well thought out security gates. We finally have a sense of security for our cars parked in the parking lot. Very courteous security guards. Janitors maintain the facility with a lot of care and cleanliness. Womens toilet is always sparkling.
cons: I wish I could say that there is as much job security as the parking lot security. Hiring practices are highly questionable in Protein Therapeutics and Biologics Lead Discovery Group . Team members and collegues are not given the oppurtunity to participate in hiring decisions. The VP of the group covertly nods and hand picks select members in the hiring/interview team which causes bias in hiring.

review_title: BMS, a company as whole and the department I am at, overall are positive
pros:
-good work balance
-good location
-many resources from aalmost every aspect of drug development
-lots of talent people
-Overall positive environment
cons: No growth opportunity, silos, not enough opportunity for internal growth, not even a starting point. Managers play nepotism. Always seek candates from outside, which is wrong.

review_title: BMS co-op experience has been excellent. I was able to learn a lot through actual projects and my relationships.
job_title: Business Analyst Intern in Plainsboro, NJ
pros: I worked at BMS as an intern, where I was able to receive excellent support and guidance by the full-time business analysts. I also had full exposure to the business procedures, business negotiations, and behind-the-scenes analysis As an intern, I was free to initiate meetings with people on other departments to conduct information interviews; I found this especially helpful in learning about other people's career paths and professional lessons.
cons: One thing I didn't really like about corporations is the cubicles, where I was very self-conscious whenever I was on a phone call - I felt like everyone could hear what I was saying (even if people weren't paying attention).

review_title: Good place in many but not all ways
pros: World-class science, great colleagues, excellent pipeline.  No large pharma company has done better than BMS at getting new drugs on the market: nearly every company that has put similar numbers of drugs on the market has spent much more per new drug on R&D than BMS has.
cons: Decision-making can be bureaucratic at times, but no more so than in other large companies.  The biggest issue I have is that strategy changes are not fully explained, nor is stakeholder input sought prior to making a decision.  Also, in recent years there seems to be more of a preference for hiring new people with needed skills, as opposed to retraining existing people.

review_title: Only for the experienced with long resume
pros: Lots of opportunities in a growing site. Willing to hire fresh grads. A robust product pipeline with an expanding modern infrastructure for scientific work. Many young talents in an old pharma. Great work location for families.
cons: Project assignment and promotion is largely based on favoritism or fear of loosing critical project contact point. Strong hierarchy with many scientists having only 1 direct report, and then the scientist hardly show up in lab anymore. Town hall meetings are typically met with a silent audience who are too afraid to speak out in fear of ensuing unfair treatment. Little room for growth if not among the favored.

pros: Work life balance good depending on function. Decent benefits. Salaries are not competitive. Ability to learn new skills. Get to interface with new tech.
cons: Management is not well structured. Compensation and ability to grow your career is severely limited. Budget is heavily cut which results in minimal travel/no conference support. HR claims they care about employees, but really it's just protecting the bottom line. Stability is uncertain due to increasing outsourcing. Favoritism is rampant in some places. Too much beaucracy with decision making and functioning.

review_title: All things considered, a well-run company
pros: I've worked for a few different pharmaceutical companies, small and large, and BMS is probably the best of the lot.  Well-balanced in its approach to business and its people (employees and patients).  I would return to BMS if the right opportunity presented itself.  Behaviors weigh heavily in the performance management process, as they should.
cons: Honestly, I can't come up with many downsides to working for BMS.  There does seem to be a "higher than average" level of change.  I know that people say that "change is good" - and I am a firm believer in that concept - but it does seem that BMS may be trying too many things in a short amount of time without letting some of the changes play out to see how the decision making is going.

pros: BMS's continues to universally on core competencies for all employees and then ties these to timely appraisals and compensation. What you see on billboards, mission and vision statements is what employees can expect to see at appraisal time. Every division has indigenous brand or customer segment behavioral and performance expectations but corporate culture and how employees deal with each other is driven by  visible, interwoven, and daily communicated core behaviors. No doubt exists and if employee has any questions, they are addressed quickly and uniformly.
cons: Sometimes, discipline can seem overbearing on creativity but the core behaviors are universally agreed-on by consensus meetings and the eyes and ears are constantly alert for any employee or group that feels their creativity or ability to look outside the box is threatened.

review_title: Learn to Navigate the Political Matrix
pros: Colleagues were committed and for the most part collegial not competitive.  Once you are a part of the organization, a good performer will be given developmental opportunities to advance.  Benefits when I was there were excellent(company pension,401k match, stock options/grants,health insurance, PTO) although I've heard company pension is no longer as of this year(2010).
cons: So goes senior leadership, so goes the confidence you have in the organization and it was a roller coaster of folks my 15 years there from very poor to very good.  On again/off again lay-offs and hiring has led to a significant amount of loss of institutional knowldege, so many lessons get re-learned time and again at the expense of expediency and efficiency.

review_title: Mixed Bag, Proceed With Caution if Considering!
pros:
-Salary/Benefits/perks
-Location/commute
-Flex work schedules for some (not all)
-WDYWF? patient initiative
-Solid products; strong presence in the marketplace
-Key people with excellent leadership qualities and skills( people who are more than managers and understand the difference).
cons:
-Too many fast org changes this year have been disruptive
-Some areas need stronger leadership and management, as some managers are just ticking off requirements on checklists and are not really engaged with their subordinates
-Poor employee retention/constant turnover in some areas 
-Working with remote teams is a challenge (it's been over 18 months and I'm considering a move already). Sometimes a dysfunctional team is too entrenched and can not change for the better.

review_title: Unfulfilled a very disorganized and dysfunctional company
pros: The company has great benefits and if you are ok to go with the status quo in a very mundane environment then give it a go.
cons: Disjointed and erratic work environment.  Given objectives and mandates with no budget or support to meet these requests.  A whole lot of fancy dancing and finger pointing to shift blame for poor sales and P&L concerns.  They had an easy ride with great drugs and are now trying to be "No 1 in Diabetes with two lame oral products for Type II Diabetes; just a bit unrealistic and arrogant.

pros: International environment, canteen, Christmas dinner,  outdoor activities, volunteering.
cons:
Employees who work in this company for many years and who have much experience are not valued/appreciated here.

Headcount is frozen due to Brexit and possible relocation to another country as it happened with accounts payable department in 2017. Everyone fears to loose their job, causing a bad environment to work in.

You will only thrive and continue working in this company if you have a close relationship/friendship with your manager and upper management. 

When there is a job offer they most likely give it to someone who is an acquainted of one of the managers either with or without the necessary skills/experience rather than to someone with a good CV. 

Recruitment process was long and unorganized and connection with HR department while working here is almost inexistent.

Working on bank holidays and saturdays.

pros: There were a ton of GREAT Middle managers, they were all very caring and concerned with work/life balance- benefits, flexibility, Teamwork,
cons: Laid off workforce of IT workers and subcontracted out ownership of network services to Large Vendors... instead of signing on for a trial period, it was a 10 year deal and in very short order, everything became a separate charge... must have cost BMS millions in lost funds and slowed down work compared to keeping its IT in house

pros: I worked for BMS for over 10 years.   Very mission-driven, focused on the patient.   Smart people to work with who are very accessible.   Opportunity to do meaningful work and make an impact.  Fond memories of working there and I sometimes miss it.
cons: Re-orgs every year become predictable after a while.   Living in worry of losing your job is added stress and could cause people to lose focus.

review_title: Take the good with the bad
pros: Great pay for Tampa, smaller office (~500) with a larger company infrastructure (great benefits, etc.).  Senior site  leader is authentic and cares about people.  The mission of serving patients is amazing!
cons: Going through 'vision 2020' which is another way of saying they are downsizing.  Career growth is non existent and the employees from NJ think Floridians are uneducated idiots that are only capable of transactional work.

pros: Management acts in a manner that shows they really care about their employees. Employee development plans are well thought-out and employees have the opportunity to suggest things like future training programs or just general feedback. They do a lot to make sure their employees are engaged and feel like they have what they need to enjoy work.
cons: I can't think of a significant cons. There are a few minor annoyances related to the work environment that aren't even worth mentioning because it's just a matter of personal preference rather than things that most people would be bothered by. No company is perfect so there's always something that one could complain about.

review_title: Company does not seem to be very interested in Diversity.  If your manager dislikes you, your numbers don't matter.
pros: Bristol Myers Squibb offers great benefits, company car, and expenses paid.  The job is not difficult.  If you are lucky to have a FAIR manager and you see your doctors you should be successful.
cons: The company is not concerned with DIVERSITY.  Some of the manager's are inexperienced, unprofessional, and unfair.  If you have a manager who dislikes you for whatever reason, numbers and a successful territory don't matter.  The manager is allowed to give a bogus performance evaluation and Human Resources does nothing to support the representative.

pros: Generally collaborative environment within the various business units, opportunities for young aggressive employees, good perk (summer hours from May until Sept).  Generally good people to work with.
cons: BMS is continually downsizing its employee base, outsourcing and moving operations to low cost locations.  Stress level of remaining employees is high.  More global responsibilities mean working hours increase and expectation is that you are available for conference calls at all hours.  Policies and systems put in place create more bureaucracy.  Do not really do a good job of understanding the impact of executive decisions in various functions and how they impact those who are tasked with doing the work.

review_title: Innovative pharma company but still need to build team spirit
pros: Competitive compensation package, innovative company with a strong pipeline, fast business growth, great location near Zug lake, very international group, company is investing in the Cham location
cons: The company is currently going throug a large business transformation, closing sites, moving positions from one location to another whithout proper planning for transition. The site in CH only exist since 3 years so there is mo strong bounding between people, it feels like it's a group of individuals with functions which do not need to interact with each other so at the end everyone spend their time having phone calls all day long to connect with people who they work with on day to day basis but who are not in the same country/continent and they end up not knowing at all the people sitting next to them in the office...

review_title: BMS is a fine place to work (if you like New Jersey)
job_title: Market Research Manager in Plainsboro, NJ
pros: Kind, competent, engaged colleagues who in general tend to have respect for work/life balance; compensation and benefits are about par for the industry; good cafeteria (but price increases are making it less and less affordable); on-site daycare and drycleaning
cons: Living in NJ with its high taxes and cost of living really eats into your compensation; on-site credit union is a joke in terms of the rates offered; too many ex-sales reps in marketing perpetuate the dying sales model of big pharma (still too much emphasis on carrying a bag); tightening of budgets has lead to more bureacracy and red tape so they talk about being nimble but you are hamstrung in actual decision-making waiting for countless approvals

job_title: R&D Process Development Engineer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Employees get to play a part in helping people with serious ailments get treatment.
Work is intellectually stimulating and challenging.
cons:
Very little autonomy. Do what you're assigned to do, and don't expect much say in growth opportunities
Heavy on favoritism, not really performance-based even though a lot of time is spent writing performance reviews.  Many of the top performers find better opportunities elsewhere in the company or at other companies.  Few stay longer than 5 years or so.
Corruption scandal while I was there:  executive VP of R&D (I believe that was his title) was having affair with and giving preference to employee.

review_title: I was over-stressed and dissatisfied. No room for advancement.
pros: I liked that they provided amenities such as a daycare on premises; Gym, etc. The cafeteria is fairly decent as well. Office spaces are much better than some of the other companies. Laxed dress code was also much appreciated.
cons: There was a lot of nepotism--it didn't matter how hard you worked but the promotions and raises were always given to the favorites. It became increasingly demotivating to work in an environment like that. There also wasn't much flexibility to have a better work-life balance, even though this was emphasized by the company on paper. At the end it felt like the negatives outweighed the positives.

review_title: Good place to work but depends on your goals!
pros: Location, away from the city.  Love the people I work with and the pay is decent.
cons:
The only REAL con I have is this:

12 Hour Shifts have been forced on us with no overlap between 1st and 2nd shift!  EVERYBODY hates the hours but the new management came in with this change in mind and didn't care what the employees thought!  The training program is basically non-existent...if you're not a super self-motivated person it can be hard to learn the process and gain opportunities .

review_title: A Once Great Company Now in A Death Spiral
pros: If I was asked a year ago to provide a list of "Pros" related to working for BMS, the list would have been extensive. My response to the same question today...not many "Pros" to working at BMS during this very tumultuous time of company transformation.  We are hemorrhaging great talent and nobody seems to care as attrition is viewed as a mechanism to allow the company to achieve it's talent reduction targets. Having to watch so much talent and vibrant leadership walk (or be forced) out the door, I made the difficult decision to leave this sinking ship.  But if you love shiny new ultramodern infrastructure, Princeton Pike may be a great place for you to work.
cons:
-Staff reduction decisions being made with no regard for performance history or years of service.  
-Employees still standing are completely preoccupied with company transformation and trying to predict what the next round of changes will bring.  This has led to a "self-preservation" mentality - people clamoring for non optimal roles that they think will offer them a level of job security.
-Company operating model has been turned upside down in the last year (thank-you BCG!). Poor communication and expectation setting around how to work in the new model.  In short, WAY too much change in a short period of time.
-Over-reliance on a single asset - Opdivo.  
-Weak upper management driven to transform the company to be "more competitive" in the future, but in reality are dressing the company up for an acquisition.

job_title: Maintenance Tech IV in Seattle, WA
pros: In my 12 years with BMS, the company clearly demonstrated why it is considered a great place to work. In addition to being well compensated, I enjoyed the challenges and going there every day. I was among like-minded folks working to make life better for people and patients. It was a highly collaborative and supporting environment: little wonder we all considered each other family. They recognized the genuine need for a healthy work-life balance and supported the employees toward that end. We even had an annual charity auction, with all proceeds going to help the local community. Not too bad at all.
cons: Can't really think of anything worth bringing up. Every company has its issues, but I feel fortunate to have worked there.

review_title: Decent company that treats its people well.
pros: Large company with a good name on the resume.  Adequate resources and support for employees.  Support for a reasonable work/life balance.  Management treats employees well.  Good opportunities to gain experience with different functions.  Good benefits, including an excellent pension plan.
cons: Pay is below average.  Promotions are not considered until you fulfill minimum years of "seniority" within your current position.  You satisfaction can be highly dependent on your direct supervisor.  Many career opportunities would require relocation to the northeast (mostly New Jersey).  Can be too conservative with endless rules to follow  (typical of big pharma, I am guessing).  Rules for performance evaluation, compensation and career advancement may not be clear.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in Redwood City, CA
pros: Long-time employees are great- good scientists, cooperative, supportive. Flexible work schedule. Good benefits, especially 401k matching and vacation. Big budget for research.
cons: Difficult to move up, especially for veteran employees. More of a boys club, good luck if you’re a female scientist. Employees with tenures >10yrs are abandoning ship because of the deteriorating culture and low salaries. Problem employees are not dealt with and instead are given promotions and accolades by upper management.

review_title: Employees verses contractors in Clinical Research
pros: BMS employees have more flexibility with schedules, summer hours, benefits.  This is great however when you have the majority of the culture who are contractors it does make it hard to see colleagues and friends be denied the same flexibility when we have the exact same role.
cons: Contractors do not have any flexibility with schedules anymore, no summer hours, and are treated extremely different by senior management.

review_title: Overall a good company to work for.  Great mission, good products.
pros: Great place for work and life balance.  Good execution on drug discovery and launching new product to market.  A company in the middle of a  major transformation that will allow it to emerge as an industry leader in the bio-pharmaceutical industry.
cons: No longer provides pension for new employees. In the past 2 years majority of employees have seen little to no increase in salary for merit performance while CEO and other senior management continue receive their merit increases and bonuses.

pros:
Strong pipeline/leader in I-O

Very nice, new facility, large amount of resources.
cons:
Upper management has no respect for the people who are actually in the lab doing the work. Racism is prevalent, and is seen as the main driver of promotions and recognitions. Scientists are moved between departments without having a choice; and sub-department re-orgs are common, in an attempt by upper management to "keep the people happy". Problem managers threaten their direct reports, punish them for working overtime, and perform poorly in general with no repercussions whatsoever. Retention issues are apparent.

All drug programs are extremely accelerated, leaving no time for scientists to actually do science. Drugs are pushed through the pipeline as fast as humanly possible without any sort of scientific verification, giving rise to problems down the line.

Minimal chance for long-term career growth. Once your promoted once, time to find a new job! That's the end of the line.

review_title: Great company & compensations, good clear strategy and organization - as long as you are not collaborating with Greece
pros: Excellent vision, diversity, opportunities to grow, excellent structure, always try to transform to be competitive!
cons: Global Public affairs dpt needs to be more professional when communicating strategies. Employees are not stupid.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Princeton, NJ
pros: BMS is a solid company with a good pipeline.  Good salaries for administrative staff.  Good benefits.
cons: Company more interested in paying higher dividends to shareholders than in employees.  Although company promises work-life balance, it depends on supervisor/management team and department.  Company expects to do more work with fewer employees so workload often overwhelming.  No recourse available if manager’s assessment is wrong or unfair.  Yearly performance evaluation not always fair/managers not required to contact feedback providers or consider their evaluations.   Hire temps instead of increasing permanent staff – don’t see hidden costs in employee turnover.

pros: Great people in the rank & file.  Great open work environment.  Great pay & benefits.
cons: The attitude at BMS is a bit "cult like"  it can seem a bit "Stepford Wives" at times.  But there is a bigger/deeper problem which is upper management is led by outside consultants -- don't believe they would know what to do if they didn't have their outside consultants directing them.  They spend literally hundreds of millions of dollars a year on consultants.   Management is very protective of those consultants as well -- to the detriment of employees.

review_title: Decent place to work and the benefits are good.
job_title: Research Scientist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Ability to learn and grow, emphasis on scientific learning and encouraging knowledge sharing. Management emphasizes research and publication as key to growth and development.
cons: Being a large institution the process sometimes gets to bureaucratic. Decisions are not always  based on sound scientific judgement. Sometimes, it feels like a dog eat dog world.

pros: Senior managements had a lot of efforts to improve company culture. Some groups are really good.
cons: Some groups are dead corners,the nice policy never interpreted correctly.

review_title: Director, employee for over a decade
pros: Has some phenomenal drugs in terms of efficacy and safety
cons: Recent high turnover in both senior and mid=level management,  both from layoffs as well as people jumping ship. Company emails keep talking about "refocusing" but not clear direction on anything other than "immuno/oncology"

review_title: Great company in general, but there's a lot going on
pros: Some people are very friendly, and this makes your day to day easier in spite of the pressure. If you aggressively take care of your career, you can keep growing. Salaries and benefits are good. The biopharma behaviors promote a positive environment to work.
cons: The path to the future is not clear. There have been so many changes that we don't know what the strategy is anymore (we actually wonder if the senior leaders have one).  We know we will get much smaller within the next 3 years.

pros: Ice cream truck Wednesdays during the summer and summer hours. Excellent maternity leave policy. The company is a good company overall, but there are just certain departments that are big problems.
cons:
People who work hard are continuously overlooked in favor of those employees who are buddies with senior management. People who do the absolute bare minimum are rewarded, while those who go the extra mile don't see it reflected in their annual review or bonus. Employees are aware of rating changes during review calibration that did not accurately reflect performance in order to benefit the "favorites." This seriously hurts morale and has a negative impact on retention. Retaliation is prevalent when complaints are made. 

Management doesn't do a good job communicating, so things tend to be all over the place and expectations can be confusing. Some managers dislike data sharing, meaning that groups often end up doing unnecessary work.

In addition, there are minimal opportunities to advance within the department (again, unless you have friends in high places).

Health insurance options are abysmal.

Science isn't valued as much as would be expected for a company that wants to be a leader in the industry. Many scientists present data without statistical analysis or duplicate experiments and tend to jump to conclusions.

Cuts to travel budgets mean fewer opportunities to go to conferences. Management has also called for a reduction in the employee recognition system "Bravo," claiming that people are over-rewarded and aiming to reduce reward values for hard work.

BMS claims to strive for a culture of inclusivity, but kept on a senior employee after multiple complaints were filed for him harassing female employees. Female employees were instead moved.

review_title: Commitment to patients, but continuous reorgs
pros: Basically a good place to work - definitely not the Evil Empire. Benefits and pay are good, work culture emphasizes the end users - the patients with the serious diseases. It makes you feel proud to be a part of that. Company emphasizes career development, so you're encouraged to learn new things and advance your career. This is also one of the few places I've worked that really means it when they say they advocate work-life balance.
cons: Biggest con is the constant structural reorganizations over the last few years. There have been some layoffs, and those left behind are in limbo while they're figuring out how to work within the new structure.

pros: The company is a big one in the market with high standards at the headquarters.
cons:
The people are promoted not based on competencies.
The direct boss / team manager does not treat everyone the same but based on preferences.
The team manager talks badly with the employees using sexual meaning words.
The colleague's are afraid to explain to the new members how to treat different scenarios since the team manager said it wants the new employee to leave because the general management decided to take this person and the team manager wanted someone else.
The manager is screaming at employees and does not have respect for the employee private time.
The manager does not provide any help to the new employee in order to make sure it integrates into the team.

All this are happening and the business unit does not know about it.

review_title: A great manager is critical, as senior management is not great.
pros: I had a fantastic manager and developed greatly under his tutelage.  He was able to give me enough growth and development opportunities for the time that I was there.  Had the ability to act quickly and independently on local issues.
cons: The department I was in was not well valued or resourced.  Working across sites was laboriously slow.  Implementation of agreed  upon decisions was often to followed through on if not favored by a particular sute.  Interdepartmental power struggles stifled innovation.  Lip service paid to the idea of development of staff by senior management.

pros: Its a company that is ever changing becoming better year by year.  Its got a strong steady strategy and unlike other companies that are trying to get bigger, BMS is trying to get smaller, more nimble, and get our specialized drugs to our patients faster.  Our pipeline of drugs is inspiring and the work we do actually makes a difference in the lives of our patients and their families
cons: There is constant change as we look to move faster and be better and sometimes this creates "change fatigue"

review_title: Big company trying to do good
pros:
-The people doing all the real work were wonderful and looked out for each other.
-Always a sense that ultimately everything we did was helping sick people get better.
-Upper management at least tried to look like they cared, especially in 2015, by having a "fun squad" hold events like $1 hot dog day and live music.
cons:
-Typical uncaring upper management making sweeping arbitrary decisions with no regard for employee loyalty.
-Little room for advancement
-Lately most employees are living under the constant threat that their jobs (and entire departments) will suddenly be eliminated

review_title: Once the economy improves this will be a sinking ship
pros: New CEO and other top level execs want real change to make this company into a world class biopharma.  IT is adopting industry standard process (ITIL, PMP etc).
cons: The old guard is doing a great job at making sure we are stuck in 1990 from a culture and technology perspective.  There is no room for advancement in IT unless you have an MBA.  I have noticed that no-one with a advanced technical degree being promoted beyond the D6 level.  There are no D5s in IT to my knowledge.

review_title: Changing a lot, not in a positive way
pros: The people for the most part, the compensation and the flexibility
cons:
The company transformation has been going on for a few years and many employees are burnt out. The management does not seem to be paying much attention to it. The headcount is cut and the work is dumped on the remaining employees versus taking a look at the work, understanding what needs to stop/start/continue and allocating it to the resources left.
Hiring new employees with inappropriate behaviors.
Many of high performing employees have been leaving the organization. It's a shame that the management does not act to retain its talent.
Career opportunities are now quite limited at a certain level since most of the lower level roles have been moved to Florida.

review_title: "Truly a nightmare" or "Let's toss the new guy under the bus over and over again."
job_title: Scape Goat in Mount Vernon, IN
pros:
Clean and safe work environment
Dedicated/hardworking employees for the most part
Challenging/interesting work
cons:
Zero work/life balance in some areas
HR support grossly lacking... months to back fill open positions
Few standard work processes in key areas leading to employee fiefdoms
Over-relinace on Email and IM,  grossly overused (100-150 emails per day, steady stream of IMs)
Key business processes capable, but not in control, resulting in ongoing stream of "emergencies" and fire-fighting

job_title: Management Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: BMS (when I worked there) was a fantastic company.  It has a superb HR function with great focus on talent and leadership development.  It is the type of co that welcomes mid career executive from other companies and has a healthy mix of developing internal talent and acquiring external talent
cons: Back in 1990's there was a shift away from focusing on performance management to exclusive focus on developmental discussions.  Hence, the rigor on performance mgmt was lost and may have affected the co's performance in the early 2000's.

job_title: Associate Product Manager in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros: Exciting new oncology innovation. Strong cardiovascular brand. Good pay like most pharma. Easier than CPG marketing (if you don’t mind having zero impact or influence)
cons: Overly political culture. You need to be from sales and over 50 years old to have a say in anything strategic. No upward mobility due to a lack of cutting poor talent. Poor leadership for all the same reasons. If you like being paid too much for no impact, but plenty of political BS, this is the place for you.

pros:
The culture seems to be friendly and connected.
New Management is starting to address the issues.
Old management stuck in their ways has moved onward
cons:
Salary was not negotiated too much and rather low balled too. 
Lots of bureaucracy - but being addressed by new leadership.
Things seem to be more complicated then they need to be with overly processed approaches to their work.  Needs more streamlining and simplification.

review_title: Great Place to Work but Very bureaucratic
pros: What better way is to spend your time curing cancer.  The overall mission of the company is great to be a part of.
cons: Most of upper management is not approachable and some are very cruel.  They say they promote team work but i have never worked at a company before where there was less teamwork and more back biting in my entire career.  Also very hard to get a promotion, most people have to leave in order to be promoted.

review_title: Great job but also fast paced and quite stressful
pros:
-Great benefits and compensation
-Lots of days off if working on 12hr shift schedule + Good number of vacation/holidays
-Generally helpful and encouraging team
-Intellectually stimulating job, constantly new things to learn
cons:
-Momentum picks up extremely fast once the training "break in" period is over
-Very complex process with heavy use of automation = tons to learn, and can be overwhelming at times

pros: Departmental Community Atmosphere, Telecommuting Allowed, Great Managers, Encouragement for Educational Enrichment, Great Benefits, Excellent Cafeterias and Health Centers, Very Professional Corporate Environment.  Travelers stay at very good hotels.  Team work is highly utilized and in a great way.
cons: Making employees drive back and forth to various NJ sites as instead of using excellent in house technology for meetings.  Not enough telecommuting is promoted.  Politics can be a little rough depending on department.  Upper level management not in touch with needs of worker bees.  Mid-level management is overworked and highly politicized internally.

review_title: Wow. The North America Capability Center in Tampa has turned out to be a great career decision for me.
pros: Great people, great culture. Excellent local leadership and regular visits by leaders in the northeast. The environment is wonderful and management is open, friendly and helpful.
cons: I wish they had local food service here, but they are just starting operations so maybe in the future

pros: Salary rate is competitive
cons: The recent management team is very poor and filled with unqualified managers. most of the managers haven't any background in management or even have any notion of basic principles of management.  An employee isn't judged and promoted based on the quality of their job, but base on relations and hypocrites. The strategy and organization are always changing with no real and solid model. As the only aim of the company is earning money, the mission of helping patients is completely lost.  The management team is downsizing in different sections of the company and moving to India which decreases the level of quality of trails and collaboration with investigators. The organizational changes are applied without no strategy.  If you are an intelligent person with a  strong personality and disapprove hypocrisy who wants to learn and grow, BMS is not a place for you to work!!

review_title: Get ready for constant change and up upheaval
pros: The benefits are decent though shrinking, you receive some autonomy and the other employees seem to care about their jobs.
cons:
Shrinking benefits and perks...canceled pension, cafeteria costs rise, company store closed etc.
Absent management - recent changes and they've all but disappeared
Constant change for change sake
Fear seems to be the current management style
People who can get new jobs are heading for the doors

pros:
Good benefits and a pension plan...but they can change at any time.
If you can play the politics, you will go far;  however, if you actually have a work ethic and morals...you are absolutely screwed!
cons:
There is no integrity, competence, or human component to this company.  The people are required to work a lot of hours, only a select few receive good raises, and the politics are out of control.
We have these core values that determine our performance bonuses, but none of the management team or the senior level management have these values:  integrity, innovation, leadership, energizing others...etc.
There is no morale left in the company, everyone is waiting for the axe to fall, and management is absolutely horrible.

job_title: Territory Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Was once a great industry that did what was right by docs, patients and employees.  you have control over your own time. You can use your brain, but it has to be on your own.
cons: Pharma is not a growth industry. Some VERY greedy people spoiled the whole apple cart so that now lawyers and the government are setting the rules of play.  Now we are regulated to the nth degree and creativity is viewed as non compliance. We have some very over price senior management and we have NEVER held accountable those that caused us to botoom out

pros: Great benefits.  Good company culture outside of Phoenix facility.  Make products that help people.
cons: This facility has huge issues with favoritism.  Promotions are based on friendships with leadership and perception rather than performance and contribution.  Many promotions/positions are filled without ever opening the job or considering multiple candidates.  Senior management is inflexible and not open to feedback, but quick to blame their subordinates for the negative outcomes of their own decisions.  There is no diversity in upper management and very little in middle management.

review_title: Get in, get experience and then leave for someplace better....
pros: If you manager allows you too, you can telecommute (work from home). Unfortunately, many do not believe in doing this.
cons: They re-org every year. They layoff every year. There is no room from advancement. If you are on the A list, then good for you. If you are on the B list you're pretty much screwed. No professional development, they always claim to never have the money to train  employees. Team building is generally a waste of time. No one adheres to the Core Behaviors. It's all about politics. You are working with Service Providers who give unsatisfactory service.

review_title: overall great company to work for
job_title: Associate Research Scientist I in Princeton, NJ
pros: Opportunity for advancement, benefits, great vacation time allotment, opportunity for tuitition reimbursement
cons: Promotion involves your manager needing to "fight" for you in front of other groups within the department - if you have a manager that doesn't really care, good luck getting a promotion. Hours can change based on experiments run, no overtime pay. Hard to balance work/life sometimes. Getting more responsibilities doesn't necessarily mean a promotion is on the way, just more work for average pay (salary is not that great).

pros: The company and management treat employees as professionals. Over the years, the company has been pursuing inclusiveness and diversities. The company has a mentor program which allows employee to connect with leaders and senior managers and have dialogues around their career developments.
cons: The company started its reform since 2005. the continuing improvements and innovations have transformed the company from a traditional pharmaceutical to a bio-pharmaceutical company. However, because of these changes are no-stopping, it has generated many uncertainties to career opportunities of the company.

job_title: Associate Scientist II in Hopewell, NJ
pros: I loved everything about this job. My manager was amazing, the work/life balance was great, plenty of flexibiility, pay was competitive. Lots of opportunities to learn and grow professionally.
cons: They're closing the Hopewell site and it's impossible for me to commute to New Brunswick, so I was forced to look for another job. I'd still be there if they weren't closing. In fact, I would have worked my whole career and retired from that company.

job_title: Research Scientist in Redwood City, CA
pros: I’ve worked at several companies and I can say this is the best place I’ve worked for. We have a phenomenal group of individuals who are dedicated to both the patients and the science. While this site has undergone some transformations in the last year, the change has been for the better. Managers are much more involved in the career development of their employees and ensuring a positive culture and work/life balance. We now also have great perks such as gym and commuter subsidies.
cons: Bay Area is expensive and compensation should be adjusted for all current employees accordingly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mount Vernon, IN
pros: Benefits are excellent, great work/life balance, understanding leadership, continuous improvement in all areas.
cons: The pharmaceutical industry in general is demanding. I've had to come in on multiple weekends and holidays, but with the economy being the way it is, I'm more than willing to work a little more in order to hold a stable job. The cafeteria in Mt. Vernon is outsourced to Sodexo, which charges an arm and a leg for a sub-par meal. Thankfully, there are some good food choices down the road, or just bring your lunch. No big deal.

review_title: Poor communications, disjointed and way too many meetings to plan meetings.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I did get to interact briefly with some very personable and competent middle managers. Otherwise the circumstances and the short duration of the employment  were not conducive to finding any other pros.
cons: Too many "coordination" meetings that failed in their primary objective (too keep other working groups abreast of what was going on). Too many meetings to plan meetings - many of these could have been accomplished by email with delegated tasks with results back to the group. I also experienced poor implementation of HR processes that were supposed to support our group.

pros: Good vacation allowance and sick time, good 401K match -100% to 6%.  Northeast Site (Devens) is in nice location, right off highway.  Coworkers are generally good to work with, although some moral boosting would do all well. Company is investing in site and has a bright future.
cons: Typical corporate crap - bonus way below what it should have been given recent stock price jump.  Upper site management sometimes aloof of realities in Manufacturing.

review_title: Tough to work in sales here unless you can turn your brain off
pros: Pay is decent, especially in the specialty divisions. R&D plus acquisitions seem to promise good growth potential which would hopefully lead to some job security.
cons: Almost impossible to work here unless you can disconnect your brain and take direction from central command and control. Worse yet, most of the people giving the commands rotate through their jobs every 1-2 years but still think they know all the answers. pros: Benefits,a job in this tough economy.
