Management uses a lot of buzz words such as "continuous improvement" and "breaking down silo's" however nothing has noticeably changed in the last 3 years.  Decisions are made very slowly at a very high level, and often times management changes mind multiple times.  Morale is terrible, and management does nothing to improve morale.

review_title: Great Work/Life Balance and Compensation too!
pros:
-Work life balance (summer Fridays, working from home, flexible scheduling)
- Good compensation
- Special projects
- Ability to move around and stay with the company
cons:
- Hard to get promoted despite great performance reviews
- Lots of outsourcing
- Constantly changing business strategy without letting the dust settle
- Despite trying to be agile, the company has a long way to go
- Too many meetings lead to not enough time to innovate

pros: The company has amazing trials coming down the pike.
cons: Management is horrible. They disregard your needs, overwork you and blatantly affect your career path. You will never move up in this company because the people who matter refuse to have your interests in mind.

pros: Good training, great access to resources, annual pay rises, bonuses.
cons: American stone age style of time administration, missed time deducted from holidays not from pay with no chance of regaining time, first two hours of any overtime is given free to the company. no Time In Lue. A feeling of low morale in all locations. Outsourcing currently pandemic in most departments. Unions are forbidden in new sites and are being phased out of existing sites, except of course in France.

review_title: Less oversight would be better.  Very secure and sometimes happy.
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Redwood City, CA
pros: Top of our industry, lots of collaboration and facilities.  401k match, bonus and PTO are excellent.
cons: It seems there are a lot of people and contractors here whose job it is to 'make scientists more efficient' This is no fun, and people make money selling us plasticware tracking software, databases and network groups.

review_title: Strong plan for the future, people are the variable
pros: Overall, BMS has a solid pipeline and strategy for the future in the BioPharma industry.  It's a large organization and tends to be conservative.  Pay and compensation is competitive.  Growth opportunities are also good for those willing to put forth the effort.
cons: Can sometimes but stuck with its past experience as a distractor to innovation.  Some senior level management seem inexperienced and/or not fully developed or groomed for current responsibilities.  Work life balance can be a challenge at times.

pros: Usually engaging environment, which allows autonomy and growth. Everyone is very friendly and thoughtful. A lot of good technical talent.
cons: There are a lot of mid level management from the earlier years, which are overly conservative in adopting innovation and challenging the status quo. Senior management seems willing to listen and with enough support, will entertain new ideas. However, the mid level typically wont stick there neck out. I have been fortunate to have many good managers, but all too much its an uphill battle to bring about change.

pros: Fantastic benefits, hours, management and work-load. Everyone in management is highly focused on results, and are always happy to help you achieve your yearly goals
cons: Big companies bring big stagnant culture. Bristol has moved from large scale small molecule manufacturer to a leader in biologic oncology drugs. But I found opportunity for early career starters quite lacking, settling into the daily routine and being stuck in that rut is all too common for the young employees of this company.

review_title: Great company, I hope it continues to move forward in a positive direction...
pros: I worked at the Tampa location and it was amazing. It's an open work space which encourages collaboration. Most of the employees are very nice. The company has employee resource groups where anyone can join. This helps you network and showcase some hidden talents/ interests you may have. The company is very supportive of technological advances and input from their employees.
cons: There was a lot of changes going on towards the end of my time with the company. And since these changes were confidential, it made one feel a bit anxious as to their future within the company.

pros: The teams I worked with are fantastic, most of the members are dedicated, capable, driven and collaborative with the common goals to meet the deadline and deliver high quality products. The mid-management teams are very supportive and open minded as well.
cons: There are uncertainties about the company's direction and where the upper management team is leading the company, which caused anxiety at team level. The workload is always very high, and resource is limited, hard to maintain work/life balance.

review_title: BMS ain't great but it ain't bad
job_title: Associate Marketing Director in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros: Large company with many different opportunities. Location in central jersey is good for those that don't want to live in northern jersey with the rest of the pharmas
cons:
Well it always seems like we screw something up but to be honest I really don't think it's any worse than any other company. They all have their problems. They might be different but they all have issues. 
The one downside is they are a really cheap company- not just salaries but in terms of travel and expenses. It's pretty ridiculous and demoralizing at times- they even make you share offices.

review_title: I actually like this place, despite my numerous complaints.
pros: Good people, good products, low stress environement, good work/life balance, current strategy makes sense
cons:
BUREAUCY
Slow decision making
Politics are rampant
I
 don't believe they are sincere about "developing talent", they talk about it but the promotions and money are don't follow.

Every time there is a re-org upper management gives speaches that you know are direct from the consultants mouths.

My particular division is run with the President acting as a dictator (but don't think that's company wide)

job_title: Research Scientist II in Wallingford, CT
pros: The company takes its commitment to treating unmet medical needs very seriously. Great scientific staff. Everything you need to do your job well is at your disposal.
cons: Changing industry needs have affected BMS just like other pharma companies. Layoffs of scientific staff have been a regular occurrence, every 18-24 months. To their credit, most of those layoffs have been small in number except for the most recent. It might be a while before the industry stabilizes around a new model.

review_title: Management has no clue and is running down the company.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Princeton, NJ
pros: good work life balance. In general people are nice. Good place to learn in IT. Relaxed atmosphere.
cons:
Senior management has no clue. Lots of politics and Buddy System at senior management level.
No reward for being competent. Favor people who show off/talk.
Top heavy management. Most people are there 10+ years. There is no way to grow unless the top level people retire. There are lots of mess ups in IT - they have lots of products doing same thing. Instead of internal cost cutting, management decided to outsource IT to Accenture and EDS.

review_title: Work & life balance is deeply integrated into the work culture, something you will always appreciate.
job_title: Project Manager, Information Management in Plainsboro, NJ
pros: This is a company that clearly understands work/life balance at all levels within the organization. Further, it is a rewarding feeling to know that you are working to help the company improve and save lives.
cons: The salary levels for IT work could be better, but this is more of an issue for those who have previously worked in other industries where compensation is higher but the the concept of work/life balance are almost non-existent.

pros: Significant work life balance opportunities with flexible hours or work location. Good product pipeline. Good , smart people - both those still at BMS as well as those no longer there. Many within organization want to really make a difference. Able to accomplish some significant innovation and results with strong matrix partnerships.
cons: Over time, diminishing resources coupled with greater processes has increased work to accomplish same, or less. Notably, inclusion in presentations with management have become limited to a small handful or only one person from a team or organization. In past, there was greater inclusion and ability to present to sr leadership of the organization.

pros: You will work with an excellent combination of highly qualified young folks and industry veterans. There is a serious concern for the patient in their decisions.
cons: Political divisions on all levels - department, division - result in an inability to drive change as quickly as the marketplace requires. This means you may be working on great stuff, with great people, but improving things across political divisions will take extreme effort.

pros: Immuno-Oncology leader. There are some very bright, talented people who work at BMS. Because of the attention BMS has received from its focus in immuno-oncology, it is easy to connect with the external business and oncology community.
cons: Unstable work environment. The talented, hard working people don't stay at BMS. It is not uncommon to see one person stealing another person's work and then claiming it as his own. Senior managers are afraid to make decisions. Executive management doesn't communicate broadly or effectively.

review_title: Don't love a company because it can't love you back
pros: Opportunity to work on novel, life-changing medicines with other passionate scientists and engineers.
cons:
Bureaucratic, hierarchical organization.   The corporate ladder is constantly in your face.  The result is a widespread resentful workforce and a dysfunctional environment. 

Middle management is torn between protecting/leading their direct reports and meeting the expectations of their own management.  

Lip-service is given to continuous improvement projects but hurdles for innovation are immense.

review_title: Great Company, Lackluster Pay for Lower Level Employees
pros: Great teams, benefits, vacation.  People are generally open to helping you develop and teaching you the ropes BUT you need to learn fast and put in 110% effort.
cons: Imbalance of hard workers against those just getting by. Peers at other companies are paid more for seemingly less work.  Focus less on non-core competencies of the role.

review_title: If your not OK with change, don't apply
pros: Work life balance is very manger dependent but can be the best part of working for the company.
cons: There is constant change at BMS, employees don't feel secure or that there is a future.  If you are not ok with change in a risky environment don't apply.

review_title: A company who tried to do right but had some serious problems with some upper managers.
job_title: Senior Territory Manager in Jonesboro, AR
pros:
They funded a retirement plan and it did not have to come out of your income.
Good vacation policy.
Lower level management Region and below were excellent on the whole
They were making change in upper management that seemed to be working as I left.
cons:
Serious problems with some upper management types who eventually were shown the door but they almost ruined a great company. 

There seemed to be a time when they were trying to run people off for no reason.

review_title: My experience at Bristol-Myers Squibb has been a relatively positive one.
job_title: Research Associate IV in Redwood City, CA
pros: We do have a decent pipeline and the Redwood City site seems to be responsible for a better than average amount of the progress.  People are generally friendly.  The 401K contribution is average, the  salary is average to high, and the medical and dental benefits are average.
cons: There is no path for personal development in general.  It really depends on which group you are in and whether your supervisor is comfortable with pushing to get things done for you.

job_title: Senior Territory Business Manager in Houston, TX
pros: BMS is one of the best Pharma/Biotech companies in the business. They hire exceptional people at all levels and they take good care of their employees with regards to pay, benefits, opportunities for advancement, etc. which leads to some very loyal, longer term employees.
cons: It's a big company so naturally sometimes things can move at a slower pace but BMS is well resourced and has teams of people working challenges & projects from all angles.

pros: If you have a good local manager, that knows the reality of the job, they can give you the freedom to focus on serving the customer and the patient and avoid the no productive metrics.
cons: At the Regional management level and above, they seem removed from the reality of the sales environment, and still manage from the old: follow the marketing message and see the targets no matter the reality of the situation.

review_title: Excellent work life balance, zero room for development.
pros: BMS provides excellent work life balance, tuition reimbursement, great benefits program and work from home option.
cons: Management does not appreciate employees, barely recognition.  Seems if you do the workload of others, they do not recognize the over achievers.  In certain departments there is not room for development.  Treats consultants poorly.  Management has incredible lack of communication.

review_title: They don't care about their people and they show it everyday
pros: Work from home flexibility; vacation is decent
cons: Poor communication; it's common knowledge that they promote people to managers when they're not ready and then provide no support; they preach integrity and a positive work environment but when my manager openly bullied and harassed team members, Employee Relations stated it didn't merit action since my manager admitted that she knew she did something wrong but she didn't agree to correct her behavior; work life balance is always highlighted as the biggest weakness of the company in our yearly survey but very little is ever done to help; people are made to feel easily replaceable when bringing up issues in the workplace

pros: Overall a good company to work for. They have some good products and seem to have really changed things in the past few years with a number of good potential products in the pipeline. The people were great to work for in the main. There is the odd exception but you get that everywhere.
cons: Probably the biggest issue is that they seem to restructure every 4-5 years, so you are left to fight fr your job. The other problem can be workload, as the department I was in kept on taking people with little experience leaving others to pick up the pieces and help them along.

review_title: Great Opportunity and great place to work!
job_title: Communications Intern in Wesley Chapel, FL
pros: Great working environment in terms of the building design but also great people to work with as well
cons: Looking back I can't say there were any major cons. I enjoyed working at the NACC and for me it was a great opportunity for me to learn and develop my skills both as a person and as an employee

pros: At BMS you were never just a number, each employee was treated with respect. If you were one of the cleaning crew and a VP was walking by you in the morning, it was not uncommon for them to say, "Good Morning". BMW was very good with giving out On the Spot awards to their employees with appreciation for their hard work and dedication. You were always encouraged to advance into a better position that suited you, and not sit in a position to long
cons: Layoff's because of product decline.

pros: Company has very innovative medicines targeting diseases with high unmet needs.  BMS doesn't do generics, me too drugs or biosimilars. Company treats employees generously and does offer great upward mobility for motivated people.
cons: BMS has become overly oncology focused and needs to push into other clinical arenas. The company wants to work like a biotech, but still has many challenges: too many layers of managers that invent busy work projects to stay relevant, very conservative lawyers, and an east coast fire drill culture.

review_title: Good place for a job, but not a career
pros: BMS has excellent benefits and has an exciting pipeline of products and research.
cons: BMS has a culture of "who you know", which gives the feeling of working among cliques.  It seems that people get promotions and opportunities based on how well they are networked, rather than by how well they perform or their level of skills and experience.  I do enjoy working with BMS, but I feel as if I have to leave the company in order to have a career instead of just a job.

review_title: It could be so much better if anyone cared about someone besides themselves.
pros: Pay is good for the area but then again Syracuse is kind of an economically depressed area.  Benefits are decent for any place to work for.  The work we do overall, manufacturing and developing new drugs, is satisfying.
cons: Next to zero opportunity to grow, only the "opportunity" to do someone else's work.  You are on a track and there is no getting off that track while staying with the company, even with prior experience.  Waiting for the person in the position above you to retire or leave is not effective career development.  Recent layoffs have devastated employee morale.  Everyone is waiting for the other shoe to drop.  Newer human resources believe that most people are not qualified for the job they are already doing (even with a Bachelor's Degree in Supply Chain Management) much less any open positions that might pop up.  Turnover is getting worse as people finally move on.  Cuts are being made through this attrition.  Restructuring of the employee incentive plan will reduce bonuses.  No one knows what is going on.  If there is a plan it is not being communicated effectively in simple terms.  Management constantly uses the latest company buzz words (accountability, opportunity, focus, innovation) to explain everything going on.  I question whether or not they even understand what these words really mean.  Everything is everyone's responsibility and people I would think are paid to be responsible for particular aspects of the job have dumped that responsibility downhill.  No one in a position of authority will make a decision without creating a team or having a pile of meetings to evaluate the simplest, most basic changes.  Cover your behind and take responsibility for nothing.

review_title: Solid company trying to do the right thing. Solid pipeline.
pros: BMS is a solid company with a great pipeline. That will lead to many opportunities as the pipeline develops. Many of the difficult actions that needed to happen (plant closures, lay offs, etc) are now in the past.
cons: Being a large company, it is very beaurocratic.  In order to continue to grow, the company needs to continue to free up cash to invest in the potential of future products.

pros:
Great products in many therapeutic areas to potential work in. 
Excellent people in both commercial and medical groups.
Sound science behind the products.
cons:
Upper and middle management direction and personnel keep changing, most due to the need to climb the corporate ladder, rather than looking at longevity.
Some people are self-serving and greedy, rather than collaborative, with hidden agendas.

review_title: This is an excellent company to work for, great people, good benefits, good science.
job_title: Research Scientist I in Princeton, NJ
pros: This is a well managed company in terms of benefits, good pay, and believes in buying high quality equipment for the benefit of the scientist.  The work life balance is excellent, and most people are caring.
cons: The company senior managers are extremely driven and when I was there were more concerned with what other peer companies were working on instead of driving their internal science programs.

review_title: Job NOT as advertised, would give 0 stars if I could!
pros: Diverse selection of canteen food, lovely maintenance and catering staff, nice building and plants
cons:
Job is not as described; it is extremely dull, unchallenging and unrewarding.
I was hired for an intellectual scientific position and it turned out to be entirely administrative. 1 year on and I am still bored.

Management are labile, incompetent and hypocritical with a poor work ethic. There is no adequate leadership and redundancies are carried out all of the time. Poor team morale is evident.

Contrary to their assertions, BMS is ultimately an unethical company that puts profit before patients and employees. Tread carefully.

review_title: Great place to work, focus on the patient, but some big company politics
pros: Really focuses on the patient and its not just lip service. Employees and coworkers are great, people respect each other, and pretty modern facilities with nice comp and benefits.
cons: There's a lot of "alignment" and all that technical talk which really means there's a lot of politics, but that's partly a necessary evil when you have so many layers in an org.

job_title: Associate Engineer II in Syracuse, NY
pros:
Interface with all departments on projects, therefore you get an insight on what different departments do
Safety culture is improving
Quality culture is great
Friendly environment and people are willing to help with knowledge gaps
Management encourages professional and career development
cons:
While collaborations are great,  they tend to hinder timely completion of projects  when groups are not clear of their responsibilities
Company politics are annoying; I tended to dislike break room chats so might explain why I hate the politics

review_title: A solid opportunity for career growth and a skill building job
pros:
The people across the organization are top notch talent and are very collaborative.
Marketing Training is gold standard
Products extend and enhance human life
It is possible to build a career in the opportunities at BMY
cons:
Location in Central, NJ is less than ideal, but could be worse.
Downsizing rather regularly these days, but who isn't?
Bureaucracy is still very prevalent.

review_title: Good company but currently in flux
pros: Good benefits. Nice work / life balance. Most colleagues great and easy to work.
cons: Your happiness will vary depending on who you report to. In some cases it is great in other cases it can get downright vindictive and very ugly. As with most HR departments, they tend to turn a blind eye except in the most egregious examples of management abuse.

pros: BMS is one of the strongest pharmas right now, with an excellent pipeline and a lot of excitement about the company's future.
cons: Like many other big pharmas, BMS leans heavily on acquisitions to sustain its pipeline.  That means frequent re-organizations, layoffs, "strategic re-alignments," etc as the people at the top try to keep things from getting out of control.  For most of the company, that means job stability is very tenuous, and internal research may not have time to come to fruition before yet another new visionary leader disrupts everything again.   The impact on company culture and morale is significant.

review_title: Good company, great portfolio, too much politics
pros: Overall a nice company to work for. It has a great portfolio, the market share seems to be increasing in most of the major markets, very experienced workers in the European headquarters, outstanding team working in Japan (hands off, the best team worldwide), good working environment, average work-life balance. The company is implementing several changes in a row, which is good because there is a number of things requiring true improvement. It will become a great place if they keep the same change pace.
cons: Recognition is still below par and can be hugely improved (hurry up, some good guys are leaving the company for the lack of recognition and team building). Too much politics and bureaucracy, extremely poor HR department/approach, vague promises. Too many random decisions, several tasks/activities/meetings that are a true waste of time/patience. The leadership is often US-driven, carrying out the US mentality that does not actually improve things. Too many show-up folks with low accountability on their projects, but constantly being promoted/recognized for their speaking abilities. Too many changes being implemented concomitantly, which leads to instability and causes discomfort throughout the company. Several lies (yup, lies!) being disseminated throughout the company about projects' goals, results and impacts. Low pay rate when compared to other companies in Europe. No time available for development, and development is not always encouraged. Poor project distribution and often unfair recognition of their outcomes. The Compliance department is pathetic, a disgusting joke! Culture and values are theoretically excellent, but seldom put in practice.

pros:
Real focus on why we come to work each day, for the patients. 
Interesting,  dynamic work.
Excellent 401k 
Decent LTI, with even non-management level professionals having the opportunity to earn.
Great culture that is continually evolving as we focus on the growth mindset.
Excellent opportunities for learning and development. 
Room for growth if you want it.
cons:
The Tampa office is not in a convenient location.  There is nowhere in walking distance to get lunch other than the onsite bistro. 
It takes far too much effort to let go of a poor performer.

review_title: I worked toward a goal of retirement from a good company and was cut at the knees after 8 years of service.
pros: good retirement package.  salary is good in comparison with other administrative positions in the nj/pa area
cons: Senior management is unanroachable.  mid management is not focused on the career growth and mentoring of direct reports.

review_title: A solid place to work in the pharmaceutical industry
pros: Friendly coworkers who are glad to offer their expertise when I ask. About 5 medications in phase 3 clinical trials make the company well positioned for good cash generation in the near future. The company is moving to a biopharma model to ensure sustained growth.
cons: Long walk to the parking lot for many employees. The company is streamlining to be more agile and has had several rounds of restructuring and layoffs in the past 3 years.

pros: BMS is a good company with a lot of exciting opportunities on the horizon.  There are great people at BMS who genuinely care about patients, their customers and each other.  As a large company the vacation, compensation, bonuses etc. are equal to or better than most comparable companies.
cons: The pharma industry as a whole is going through some major changes.  BMS is as well, so while there are a lot of opportunities ahead there are challenges.  How successful the culture and leadership are at adapting to these challenges while still maintaining what makes BMS a good company is still an open question.

review_title: If your ok with reorganization every 2 years this is a place for you
pros:
Great People, Management is good but depending on the person not every manager is great
Great Flexibility with life-work balance
Competitive Salary and benefits
With new open space concept, the new office space is beautiful and conducive to great work environment with plenty conference rooms
cons:
If you are not on the well liked list, no matter how good the work you do, movement within department or even outside is limited
Human Resources support management not workers

pros: Culture is improving at the Syracuse site.  4 weeks of vacation after 5 yrs service.  Dedicated employees at Syracuse site that care the site succeeds.  Communication between departments responsible for lot release has improved over the years.  Large focus on timely release of product and tracking/fixing issues that impact operations.
cons: No upward mobility, as very little turn over at Syracuse site.  Lack of talent from outside Syracuse area.   Company focus appears to be on newer biologics sites in Devens and Ireland.  Newer molecules appear to be going to other sites.  Poor planning for network harmonization.

review_title: Somedays you are working in the Ministry of Fear
pros: Some incredibly bright and talented people work here.  Now and then you may do something that positively affects the ability of someone to receive an important medication.
cons: Some real idiots work here.  The industry and company are contracting.  The level of bureaucracy is depressing.  Decision by committee means no one wants to take a risk and is a reaction to the compliance oversight, which is oppressive.

pros:
Good Co-workers
Good camaraderie with co-workers at same level
Can learn new things with the right people 
Benefits are ok
Different locations to move to
Various Departments within the company
Gyms available
cons:
Mid-management take no responsibility / blames others
Favortism is rampant in certain groups
Limited or no 'work together' mentality allowed without "permissions"
No/limited communications from mid management
Limited recognition

pros: Very well organized.  Very strong culture of leadership.  Very strong talent development culture and programs.  Outstanding group of people to work with.  Happy place to work.
cons: Bonus structure could be more rewarding.

pros: Benefits and compensation are competitive with rest of industry. Low stress environment.
cons:
Promotional opportunities are few.  So few that managers, associate directors and directors looking are doing job swap to gain experience.  Some people have been promoted but only so as to not lose the talent.  Does it make sense that a Director has only two direct reports and no other staff?

Management promised me opportunities to gain experience managing but over the last five years no opportunity arose.  My management admitted that the way the company was structured achieving my career goals would be challenging.

review_title: Solid company; genuine in desire to evolve
pros: Bristol-Myers Squibb has a progressive Global Procurement organization that inspires innovation and empowers employees to leverage their expertise and skills for maximum results.
cons: Overall, BMS is a solid with leaders who are genuinely interested in changing and evolving for the better.  However, I believe there is an opportunity to broaden their perceptions of diverse groups.  Be thoughtful about the message regarding talent diversity disparities and what will be done to change it.

job_title: Senior Clinical Site Manager in Wallingford, CT
pros:
If you did your job well line management was supportive and championed your ranking that resulted in good pay raises & bonuses.
Good pay & benefits.
Offer many diiferent types of personal development training.
Good severance packag that was based upon years of service..
cons:
Old school - limits working from to 2 days a week.
Closed Connecticut office resulting in large lay offs.  Reorganization continues at NJ offices.  I'd still be working at BMS if they handn't closed the CT location.

review_title: Good company with a great mission and great people
pros: BMS mission to help patients prevail over serious diseases is truly delivered through its product pipeline and R&D focus. Good opportunities to learn and grow in your career.
cons:
So many changes during the past 6 years affecting the management quality and retention of good employees. 
Company too focused on US and EU businesses, with a myopia of opportunities - both in business and in people management - in other key regions

pros:
-ethical company
-great drugs
-great systems to help daily work
- many initiatives you can participate and learn (kaizens, lean sigma, etc)

- Big company, decision making takes long
- Culture of rewards is not supporting employee motivation
- Extremly high workload since transformation

pros: Great atmosphere. good and friendly people from reception/catering staff to senior management. It is a nice feeling when you turn up to work (good location).
cons: Bureaucracy, complex SOPs, workloads, lack of innovation contribute to low morale among employees. Managers need to understand their line-reports and their needs and work together as a teams.  Cutting down on workload than the headcount would be the way to go.

review_title: I have been working at BMS for almost a year.
pros: Great people, competitive compensation, good work/life balance. On-site cafeteria and free gym.
cons: Hopkinton and Devens are in the middle of nowhere but there is no shuttle like many other biotech companies nearby. Normal bureaucratic slowness, kind of stingy, not as many fun company-sponsored events as my previous company which was not even doing as well. Treats PhD-level and above well but employees with BS/MS will find it more difficult to advance.

pros: May be they pay OK
cons: The senior management at this company has no clue how to run the company. Every couple of years they hire new VPs and they all come with their own agendas. there always rumors of restructuring. People are more interested in politics and not science. Managers are never interested in the career development of individuals in their teams. Lot of spineless leaders at middle and upper management. The company is constantly changing its focus. Its a very top down company. If someone has a job, they should not consider BMS as a company for career growth.

review_title: D&I for the sake of D&I
pros: Good benefits, 401k match, Bonus and easy pace of work
cons: You have to be a women or some minority to advance. The company has taken D&I to an extent that merit doesn't matter anymore. You need to belong to some group to advance, which is sad. I can get better at what I do, but I cannot change my gender or my identity so I can advance my career.

review_title: Management is way too political and too much outsourcing.

review_title: Be looking for a new position
job_title: Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: Good base pay. Coworkers are just as miserable as you are. That's about it.  This is a horrible place for an experienced rep to work.
cons: Been in this industry 20 years. This place has the absolute worst sales management you will ever find. No vision, no leadership, operate through an ever increasing mountain of meaningless paperwork and passive aggressive intimidation tactics that would be comical if not omnipresent. If you interview for a BMS position, BE SURE to ask how much turnover there has been in the district, then listen to the interviewer stammer for an answer. If you take a job here, use it as a transition to pay the bills until you find a better job.

pros: People who work here are very friendly. Good gym facilities. Decent bonuses and benefits. Nice office and flexibility to work from home one day a week.
cons: Very limited career progression with little transparency as to the promotion criteria. Under-resourced department and lack of definition of roles. Lack of documented processes and procedures means every task takes longer than it should and onboarding is too lengthy. High turnover of staff.

review_title: BBRC-Bangalore title: senior research associate. Ok researching job. Bad pay and HR behavior policies. Unplanned work.
pros:
The work culture is good. 
Technical team is oriented, well supportive and good behaviored. Engineering support team is moderately helpful.
cons:
Quality of life is just manageable. Not so great! 
The Human Resource team HR is rude and arrogant.  They have incomplete knowledge of the hiring position.  
Daily we work here giving 10+ hrs of our day,  but the financial recognition is very poor.

When an employee leaves them the HR don't know to respect the value and contribution of employee and they misbehave with employee as if she is a distorted sheet of paper. They seldom value your knowledge and experience and start talking business. In short the HR policies and rules are hopeless. The HR is a waste of their investment. The HR are the preachers of work ethics and behavior, but they themselves ruminate the lifes of employees. 
Also the appraisal comes for only one month. Feels like we are given a laddoo and Samosa at the end. Not a significant increment. The rest of the increment is kept and given at the end of next year in same fashion. Wow! I have to wait for 2 years to get my appraisal. 
The technical team is uncoordinated unplanned and dependent and the managers just want to quickly get the work done from employees. Less outputs from knowledge space for research.  Some Leaders are not a perfect role model. 
The IT team is sluggish. Blaming mentality.

review_title: Another company that puts on a shiny outward appearance, but seems to be rotting from within.
pros: Good cafeteria. Here's a few more words.
cons:
Employees are petty and backstabbing. Management does not involve employees when enacting changes, nor does management listen to the concerns and improvement suggestions of employees. Where supervisors/managers by all rights ought to be developing their employees and providing them what's needed to succeed in their roles, those responsibilities are shirked back onto employees themselves, usually without clear direction or supervision. For this reason it can take weeks to gain badge access to your area, and months to get your training "plan" accurate.

Full time jobs seem to be a thing of the past, so if you were hoping for benefits, keep looking. BMS only seems to bring on contract employees, and treats them like objects, at that.  This is regardless of your experience, education, or expertise. In all cases but 1 that I've witnessed in my time here so far, an employee whose contract is about to expire receives NO INFORMATION from BMS nor the contract agency as to future intentions. The most anyone has gotten is lip service and brushed aside. Come the fateful day, the response it's always a surprise. In one case, the poor employee was not told until the last day that he should probably look for a new job.

Another was extended 6 months, on the last day; he was vocal about his needs for decent healthcare as he required medication, nearing the end of his career. He was a bit slow to learn the computerized systems, but was surely picking it up over the months. No matter, apparently... He was let go last week for reasons that dismay the team.

On the same day last week, another older gent was let go. He had just had his contract extended another 6 months. He was told in passing by someone other than his supervisor. Fast forward two weeks, and he's being let go for something that happened in December. Why string him along like that, with not even the respect to communicate with him?

If you're looking for a REAL job, I highly suggest looking elsewhere.
